Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Enhanced Structural Health Monitoring of Civil Infrastructure Systems by Observing and Controlling Loads using Cyber-Physical Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Enhanced Structural Health Monitoring of Civil Infrastructure Systems by Observing and Controlling Loads using a Cyber-Physical System Framework

The economic prosperity of the nation is dependent on vast networks of civil infrastructure systems. Unfortunately, large fractions of these infrastructure systems are rapidly approaching the end of their intended design lives. The national network of highway bridges is especially vulnerable to age-based deterioration as revealed by recent catastrophic bridge collapses in the United States. Two major bottlenecks currently exist that severely limit the effectiveness of existing bridge health management methods. First, the causal relationship between repeated truck loading and long-term structural deterioration is not well understood. Second, current management methods are reliant on visual inspections which only provide qualitative information regarding bridge health and introduce subjectivity in post-inspection decision making. This project aims to resolve these major bottlenecks by advancing a cyber-physical system (CPS) designed to monitor the health of highway bridges, control the loads imposed on bridges by heavy trucks, and provide visual inspectors with quantitative information for data-driven bridge health assessments. The CPS framework created will have enormous impact on the national economy by enhancing public safety while dramatically improving the cost-effectiveness of infrastructure management methods. The project will also create publically available graduate-level course curricula focused on CPS technology and engages inner-city middle-school students from underrepresented groups to prepare them to pursue careers in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields.

The overarching goal of the research project is to create a scalable and robust CPS framework for the observation and control of mobile agents that asynchronously and transiently interact with a stationary physical system. While this class of problem is found throughout many engineering disciplines, the project focuses on the health management of highway bridges. The mobile agents relevant to bridge health are the trucks that load and introduce long-term damage in the bridge and inspectors who visually inspect the bridge. The task of devising a robust CPS framework will be challenged by the highly transient nature of the agents involved. Specifically, the compressed time of interaction between the truck and bridge results in tight time constraints on observation, quantification and control of the truck's loading. The project will rely on ad-hoc wireless communications to seamlessly integrate sensors embedded in the mobile agents (trucks and inspectors) with wireless sensors installed on the bridge and with servers dedicated to cloud-based analytics located on the Internet. The project will design the CPS framework to quantify in real-time truck loads based on sensor data streaming into the CPS framework. A distributed computing architecture will be created for the CPS framework to automate the decomposition of computational tasks in order to dramatically improve the speed and efficiency of the framework's data processing capabilities. Finally, the CPS framework will establish ad-hoc feedback control of the mobile agents in order to control mobile agent-stationary system interactions. In particular, feedback control of an instrumented truck allows the CPS framework to control the loads imposed on the bridge for improved health assessments. The CPS framework will be further extended to control visual inspection processes by providing inspectors with recommend inspection actions based on rigorous analysis of collected sensor data. The intellectual significance of the CPS framework is that it observes and controls truck loads on highway bridges for the first time while creating an entirely new data-driven paradigm for more accurate health assessment of infrastructure systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to develop a scalable cyber-physical system (CPS) framework that observes and controls the dynamic coupling between stationary physical systems and mobile agents interacting with them.  This class of coupled dynamic systems are found in a wide range of engineering applications including in manufacturing, electrical grids, and transportation networks, just to name a few. The proposed CPS framework was developed and applied to highway bridges (i.e., physical system) loaded by heavy trucks (i.e., mobile agents). This application is especially challenging due to the highly transient nature of the interaction (e.g., interaction only occurs when the truck is crossing the bridge) which provides a highly compressed timeframe over which interactions can be observed and controlled. The project advanced a CPS framework that integrated wireless structural monitoring systems on bridges, weigh-in-motion (WIMS) stations embedded in the road to measure truck weights, and traffic cameras installed roadside to observe trucks as they move through a highway corridor.  A major accomplishment of the project was the creation of a scalable data management system using cloud-hosted distributed NoSQL databases designed to store sensor data from the highway corridor and information representations of the bridge defined by a bridge information model (BrIM).  A key accomplishment was the creation of machine learning and computer vision algorithms to robustly identify trucks in real-time so that the monitoring systems could be triggered to measure bridge responses to load events of primary interest, namely heavy trucks.  The data collected by the CPS solution allowed the team to quantitatively model the performance of bridges during vehicle-bridge interaction, assess bridge health, and verify the operational health of the sensors deployed in the field.       

The various engineering disciplines are only beginning to explore the application of CPS architectures to complex monitoring and control problems. A major outcome of this project was a rich illustration of how CPS technologies embedded in infrastructure can provide a radically new means of monitoring and controlling very large and complex infrastructure systems. The advancement of CPS architectures in the domain of civil infrastructure will inevitably lead to: 1) a deeper understanding of how civil infrastructure systems behave under load; 2) more efficient and resilient system designs to handle those loads; and, 3) improved infrastructure system performance by controlling infrastructure as they are loaded. Specific to this project, a major outcome was the creation of novel data-driven approaches to assessing the load capacity and structural health of the bridges using data collected by the CPS architecture.  Finally, the CPS architecture was proven capable of wirelessly linking trucks crossing bridges to utilize connectivity to control the trucks to minimize the impact of their loading. To promote the research outcomes, the team wrote a large number of papers published in journals and conference proceedings associated with the fields of civil engineering, electrical engineering, computer science and cyber-physical systems. The research team had strong collaborations and interactions with practicing structural engineers in the field and at the Michigan Department of Transportation. The team also collaborated with researchers internationally to accelerate the transfer of knowledge gained from the project to impact infrastructure management globally. 

This project contributed toward the preparation of a future workforce by training engineering graduate students to advance CPS solutions in a wide range of engineering applications. The research experiences associated with the project have trained graduate students to be multidisciplinary scholars who are capable of innovating at the interfaces between engineering and scientific disciplines. One participating PhD student successfully completed a doctoral dissertation and joined a company after graduation; a second PhD student is near completion of the dissertation and is likely to join industry. The team further contributed to the preparation of a future workforce by recruiting undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in engineering to work on the project. The team was also an active participant in the Detroit Area Pre-College Engineering Program (DAPCEP) which buses primarily African American middle-school students from Detroit to spend five consecutive Saturdays at the University of Michigan to study science, technology, engineering and mathematical (STEM) topics. The team hosted two offerings of DAPCEP focused on smart structures to inspire the middle-school students to pursue degrees and careers in the STEM fields.
